Typealiases.html#/s:4Eval13VariableValue.name: VariableValue
Typealiases.html#/s:4Eval13VariableValue.abstract: A tuple with the variable metadata and its value

Typealiases.html#/s:4Eval12MatcherBlocka.name: MatcherBlock
Typealiases.html#/s:4Eval12MatcherBlocka.abstract: MatcherBlock is used by Matcher and Function classes when the matched expression should be processed in a custom way. It should return a strongly typed object after the evaluations.

Structs/PatternOptions.html#/s:4Eval14Pa.name: backwardMatch
Structs/PatternOptions.html#/s:4Eval14Pa.abstract: Searches of the elements of the pattern backward from the end of the output. Othwerise, if not present, it matches from the beginning.

Structs/PatternBody.html#/s:4Eval11Patte.name: variables
Structs/PatternBody.html#/s:4Eval11Patte.abstract: The key-value pairs of the Variable instances found along the way

Structs/PatternBody.html#/s:4Eval11Patte.name: interpreter
Structs/PatternBody.html#/s:4Eval11Patte.abstract: The evaluator instance to help parsing the content

Structs/PatternBody.html#/s:4Eval11Patte.name: context
Structs/PatternBody.html#/s:4Eval11Patte.abstract: The context if the matcher block needs any contextual information

Structs/LiteralBody.html#/s:4Eval11Liter.name: interpreter
Structs/LiteralBody.html#/s:4Eval11Liter.abstract: An interpreter instance if the raw value needs any further evaluation

Structs/DataTypeBody.html#/s:4Eval12Data.name: value
Structs/DataTypeBody.html#/s:4Eval12Data.abstract: Value of the data type to match

Structs/DataTypeBody.html#/s:4Eval12Data.name: printer
Structs/DataTypeBody.html#/s:4Eval12Data.abstract: A printer instance to use to Stringify the value

Structs/VariableBody.html#/s:4Eval12Vari.name: interpreter
Structs/VariableBody.html#/s:4Eval12Vari.abstract: An interpreter instance if the raw value needs any further evaluation

Structs/VariableOptions.html#/s:4Eval15V.name: notInterpreted
Structs/VariableOptions.html#/s:4Eval15V.abstract: If set, the value of the recognised placeholder will not be processed. Otherwise, it will be evaluated, using the interpreterForEvaluatingVariables property of the interpreter instance

Structs/VariableOptions.html#/s:4Eval15V.name: notTrimmed
Structs/VariableOptions.html#/s:4Eval15V.abstract: Whether the processed variable should be or not to be trimmed (removing whitespaces from both sides)

Structs/VariableOptions.html#/s:4Eval15V.name: exhaustiveMatch
Structs/VariableOptions.html#/s:4Eval15V.abstract: Provides information whether the match should be exhaustive or just use the shortest possible matching string (even zero characters in some edge cases). This depends on the surrounding Keyword instances in the containing collection.

Structs/VariableOptions.html#/s:4Eval15V.name: acceptsNilValue
Structs/VariableOptions.html#/s:4Eval15V.abstract: If interpreted and the result of the evaluation is nil, then acceptsNilValue determines if the current match result should be instant noMatch, or nil is an accepted value, so the matching should be continued

Structs/VariableOptions.html#/s:4Eval15V.name: interpreted
Structs/VariableOptions.html#/s:4Eval15V.abstract: In order to avoid double negatives in the source code (e.g. !notInterpreted), this helper checks the lack of .notInterpreted value in the optionset

Structs/VariableOptions.html#/s:4Eval15V.name: trimmed
Structs/VariableOptions.html#/s:4Eval15V.abstract: In order to avoid double negatives in the source code (e.g. !notTrimmed), this helper checks the lack of .notTrimmed value in the optionset

Structs/ExpressionInfo.html#/s:4Eval14Ex.name: input
Structs/ExpressionInfo.html#/s:4Eval14Ex.abstract: The raw String input of the expression

Structs/ExpressionInfo.html#/s:4Eval14Ex.name: pattern
Structs/ExpressionInfo.html#/s:4Eval14Ex.abstract: A stringified version of the elements of the Matcher object

Structs/ExpressionInfo.html#/s:4Eval14Ex.name: variables
Structs/ExpressionInfo.html#/s:4Eval14Ex.abstract: All the variables computed during the evaluation

Structs/VariableOptions.html.name: VariableOptions
Structs/VariableOptions.html.abstract: Options that modify the behaviour of the variable matching, and the output that the framework provides

Structs/VariableBody.html.name: VariableBody
Structs/VariableBody.html.abstract: It’s a data transfer object passed in the Variable matcher block

Structs/DataTypeBody.html.name: DataTypeBody
Structs/DataTypeBody.html.abstract: It’s a data transfer object passed in the DataType converter block

Structs/LiteralBody.html.name: LiteralBody
Structs/LiteralBody.html.abstract: It’s a data transfer object passed in the Literal converter block

Structs/PatternBody.html.name: PatternBody
Structs/PatternBody.html.abstract: It’s a data transfer object passed in the Pattern matcher block

Structs/PatternOptions.html.name: PatternOptions
Structs/PatternOptions.html.abstract: Options that modify the pattern matching algorithm

Protocols/PatternProtocol.html#/s:4Eval1.name: elements
Protocols/PatternProtocol.html#/s:4Eval1.abstract: Matcher instances are capable of recognising patterns described in the elements collection. It only remains effective, if the Variable instances are surrounded by Keyword instances, so no two Variables should be next to each other. Otherwise, their matching result and value would be undefined.

Protocols/PatternProtocol.html#/s:4Eval1.name: options
Protocols/PatternProtocol.html#/s:4Eval1.abstract: Options that modify the pattern matching algorithm

Protocols/PatternProtocol.html#/s:4Eval1.name: name
Protocols/PatternProtocol.html#/s:4Eval1.abstract: Optional name to identify the pattern. If not provided during initialisation, it will fall back to the textual representation of the elements array

Protocols/VariableProcessorProtocol.html.name: process(_:)
Protocols/VariableProcessorProtocol.html.abstract: The method that can process the variable

Protocols/FunctionProtocol.html#/s:4Eval.name: convert(input:interpreter:context:connectedRanges:)
Protocols/FunctionProtocol.html#/s:4Eval.abstract: Functions use similar conversion methods as DataTypes. If they return nil, the function does not apply to the given input. Otherwise, the result is expressed as an instance of a given DataType

Protocols/DataTypeProtocol.html#/s:4Eval.name: convert(input:interpreter:)
Protocols/DataTypeProtocol.html#/s:4Eval.abstract: If the framework meets with some static value that hasn’t been processed before, it tries to convert it with every registered data type.

Protocols/DataTypeProtocol.html#/s:4Eval.name: print(value:printer:)
Protocols/DataTypeProtocol.html#/s:4Eval.abstract: This is a convenience method, for debugging and value printing purposes, which can return a string from the current data type.

Protocols/VariableProtocol.html#/s:4Eval.name: name
Protocols/VariableProtocol.html#/s:4Eval.abstract: Unique identifier of the variable that is used when matching and returning them in the matcher.

Protocols/VariableProtocol.html#/s:4Eval.name: options
Protocols/VariableProtocol.html#/s:4Eval.abstract: Options that modify the behaviour of the variable matching, and the output that the framework provides

Protocols/VariableProtocol.html#/s:4Eval.name: performMap(input:interpreter:)
Protocols/VariableProtocol.html#/s:4Eval.abstract: The result of the evaluated variable will be ran through this map function, transforming its value. By default the map tries to convert the matched value to the expected type, using the as? operator.

Protocols/PatternElement.html#/s:4Eval14.name: matches(prefix:options:)
Protocols/PatternElement.html#/s:4Eval14.abstract: Using this method, an element returns how much the String provided in the prefix parameter matches the current element

Protocols/Printer.html#/s:4Eval7PrinterP.name: print(_:)
Protocols/Printer.html#/s:4Eval7PrinterP.abstract: Converts its input parameter to a String value

Protocols/Interpreter.html#/s:4Eval11Int.name: VariableEvaluator
Protocols/Interpreter.html#/s:4Eval11Int.abstract: The evaluator type to use when interpreting variables

Protocols/Interpreter.html#/s:4Eval11Int.name: context
Protocols/Interpreter.html#/s:4Eval11Int.abstract: The stored context object for helping evaluation and providing persistency

Protocols/Interpreter.html#/s:4Eval11Int.name: interpreterForEvaluatingVariables
Protocols/Interpreter.html#/s:4Eval11Int.abstract: Sometimes interpreters don’t use themselves to evaluate variables by default, maybe a third party, or another contained interpreter. For example, the StringTemplateInterpreter class uses TypedInterpreter instance to evaluate its variables.

Protocols/EvaluatorWithLocalContext.html.name: evaluate(_:context:)
Protocols/EvaluatorWithLocalContext.html.abstract: Evaluates the provided string expression with the help of the context parameter, and returns a strongly typed object

Protocols/Evaluator.html#/s:4Eval9Evalua.name: evaluate(_:)
Protocols/Evaluator.html#/s:4Eval9Evalua.abstract: The only method in Evaluator protocol which does the evaluation of a string expression, and returns a strongly typed object

Protocols/Evaluator.html.name: Evaluator
Protocols/Evaluator.html.abstract: A protocol which is capable of evaluating string expressions to a strongly typed object

Protocols/EvaluatorWithLocalContext.html.name: EvaluatorWithLocalContext
Protocols/EvaluatorWithLocalContext.html.abstract: A special kind of evaluator which uses an InterpreterContext instance to evaluate expressions

Protocols/Interpreter.html.name: Interpreter
Protocols/Interpreter.html.abstract: The base protocol of interpreters, that are context-aware, and capable of recursively evaluating variables. They use the evaluate method as their main input

Protocols/Printer.html.name: Printer
Protocols/Printer.html.abstract: A protocol which is able to express custom values as Strings

Protocols/PatternElement.html.name: PatternElement
Protocols/PatternElement.html.abstract: MatchElements are used by Matcher instances to be able to recognise patterns.

Protocols/DataTypeProtocol.html.name: DataTypeProtocol
Protocols/DataTypeProtocol.html.abstract: Data types tell the framework which kind of data can be parsed in the expressions

Protocols/FunctionProtocol.html.name: FunctionProtocol
Protocols/FunctionProtocol.html.abstract: Functions can process values in given DataTypes, allowing the expressions to be feature-rich

Protocols/VariableProcessorProtocol.html.name: VariableProcessorProtocol
Protocols/VariableProcessorProtocol.html.abstract: A processor that can process a raw value with extra information, such as interpreter and context

Functions.html#/s:4Eval14matchStatement7.name: matchStatement(amongst:in:from:interpreter:context:connectedRanges:)
Functions.html#/s:4Eval14matchStatement7.abstract: This is where the Matcher is able to determine the MatchResult for a given input inside the provided substring range

Functions.html#/s:4Eval22collectConnecte.name: collectConnectedRanges(input:statements:)
Functions.html#/s:4Eval22collectConnecte.abstract: Independent helper function that determines the pairs of opening and closing keywords

Functions.html#/s:4Eval1poiySayAA14Patte.abstract: Syntactic sugar for MatchElement instances to feel like concatenation, whenever the input requires an array of elements.

Extensions/String.html.name: String
Extensions/String.html.abstract: Helpers on String to provide Int based subscription features and easier usage

Enums/MatchResult.html#/s:4Eval11MatchRe.name: possibleMatch
Enums/MatchResult.html#/s:4Eval11MatchRe.abstract: The input can match, if it were continued. (It’s the prefix of the matching expression)

Enums/MatchResult.html#/s:4Eval11MatchRe.name: exactMatch(length:output:variables:)
Enums/MatchResult.html#/s:4Eval11MatchRe.abstract: The input matches the expression. It provides information about the length of the matched input, the output after the evaluation, and the variables that were processed during the process.

Enums/MatchResult.html#/s:4Eval11MatchRe.name: anyMatch(exhaustive:)
Enums/MatchResult.html#/s:4Eval11MatchRe.abstract: In case the matching sequence only consists of one variable, the result is going to be anyMatch
MatchResult with Equatable objects are also Equatable

Enums/MatchResult.html.name: MatchResult
Enums/MatchResult.html.abstract: Whenever a match operation is performed, the result is going to be a MatchResult instance.

Classes/Pattern.html#/s:4Eval7PatternC8e.name: elements
Classes/Pattern.html#/s:4Eval7PatternC8e.abstract: Matcher instances are capable of recognising patterns described in the elements collection. It only remains effective, if the Variable instances are surrounded by Keyword instances, so no two Variables should be next to each other. Otherwise, their matching result and value would be undefined.

Classes/Pattern.html#/s:4Eval7PatternC7m.name: matcher
Classes/Pattern.html#/s:4Eval7PatternC7m.abstract: The block to process the elements with

Classes/Pattern.html#/s:4Eval7PatternC7o.name: options
Classes/Pattern.html#/s:4Eval7PatternC7o.abstract: Options that modify the pattern matching algorithm

Classes/Pattern.html#/s:4Eval7PatternC4n.name: name
Classes/Pattern.html#/s:4Eval7PatternC4n.abstract: Optional name to identify the pattern. If not provided during initialisation, it will fall back to the textual representation of the elements array

Classes/Pattern.html#/s:4Eval7PatternC_4.name: init(_:name:options:matcher:)
Classes/Pattern.html#/s:4Eval7PatternC_4.abstract: The first parameter is the pattern, that needs to be recognised. The matcher ending closure is called whenever the pattern has successfully been recognised and allows the users of this framework to provide custom computations using the matched Variable values.

Classes/Pattern.html#/s:4Eval7PatternC54.name: elementsByReplacingTheLastVariableNotToBeShortestMatch(in:options:)
Classes/Pattern.html#/s:4Eval7PatternC54.abstract: If the last element in the elements pattern is a variable, shortest match will not match until the end of the input string, but just until the first empty character.

Classes/Pattern.html#/s:4Eval7PatternC7m.name: matches(string:from:interpreter:context:connectedRanges:)
Classes/Pattern.html#/s:4Eval7PatternC7m.abstract: This matcher provides the main logic of the Eval framework, performing the pattern matching, trying to identify, whether the input string is somehow related, or completely matches the pattern of the Pattern instance.

Classes/Pattern.html#/s:4Eval7PatternC16.name: elementsAsString()
Classes/Pattern.html#/s:4Eval7PatternC16.abstract: A textual representation of the Pattern’s elements array

Classes/Pattern.html#/s:4Eval7PatternC9s.name: stringify(elements:)
Classes/Pattern.html#/s:4Eval7PatternC9s.abstract: A textual representation of the elements array

Classes/Matcher.html#/s:4Eval7MatcherC9p.name: processor
Classes/Matcher.html#/s:4Eval7MatcherC9p.abstract: A processor that is able to evaluate the variables with extra information, such as context and interpreter

Classes/Matcher.html#/s:4Eval7MatcherC10.name: isEmbedded(element:in:at:)
Classes/Matcher.html#/s:4Eval7MatcherC10.abstract: Determines whether the current character is an OpenKeyword, so there might be another embedded match later

Classes/Matcher.html#/s:4Eval7MatcherC20.name: positionOfClosingTag(in:from:)
Classes/Matcher.html#/s:4Eval7MatcherC20.abstract: Determines whether the current character is an OpenKeyword and fins the position of its appropriate ClosingKeyword pair

Classes/VariableProcessor.html#/s:4Eval1.name: interpreter
Classes/VariableProcessor.html#/s:4Eval1.abstract: An interpreter instance to use during the processing

Classes/VariableProcessor.html#/s:4Eval1.name: context
Classes/VariableProcessor.html#/s:4Eval1.abstract: The context to use during the processing

Classes/VariableProcessor.html#/s:4Eval1.name: process(_:)
Classes/VariableProcessor.html#/s:4Eval1.abstract: Maps and evaluates variable content, based on its interpretation settings

Classes/Function.html#/s:4Eval8FunctionC.name: patterns
Classes/Function.html#/s:4Eval8FunctionC.abstract: Although Functions typically contain only one pattern, multiple ones can be added, for semantic grouping purposes

Classes/Function.html#/s:4Eval8FunctionC.name: init(patterns:)
Classes/Function.html#/s:4Eval8FunctionC.abstract: If multiple patterns are provided use this initialiser. Otherwise, for only one, there is init(_,matcher:)

Classes/Function.html#/s:4Eval8FunctionC.name: init(_:options:matcher:)
Classes/Function.html#/s:4Eval8FunctionC.abstract: In case there is only one pattern, this initialiser is the preferred one to use

Classes/Function.html#/s:4Eval8FunctionC.name: convert(input:interpreter:context:connectedRanges:)
Classes/Function.html#/s:4Eval8FunctionC.abstract: The matching of the input expression of a given Function happens in this method. It only accepts matches from the matcher, that are exact matches.

Classes/Literal.html#/s:4Eval7LiteralC7c.name: convert
Classes/Literal.html#/s:4Eval7LiteralC7c.abstract: For the conversion it uses the registered literals, to be able to process the input and return an existing type

Classes/Literal.html#/s:4Eval7LiteralC7c.name: init(convert:)
Classes/Literal.html#/s:4Eval7LiteralC7c.abstract: In case of more complicated expression, this initialiser accepts a convert block, which can be used to process any value. Return nil, if the input cannot be accepted and converted.

Classes/Literal.html#/s:4Eval7LiteralC_1.name: init(_:convertsTo:)
Classes/Literal.html#/s:4Eval7LiteralC_1.abstract: In case the literals are easily expressed, static keywords, then this initialiser is the best to use.

Classes/Literal.html#/s:4Eval7LiteralC7c.name: convert(input:interpreter:)
Classes/Literal.html#/s:4Eval7LiteralC7c.abstract: For the conversion it uses the registered literals, to be able to process the input and return an existing type

Classes/DataType.html#/s:4Eval8DataTypeC.name: type
Classes/DataType.html#/s:4Eval8DataTypeC.abstract: The existing type to map to an internal one

Classes/DataType.html#/s:4Eval8DataTypeC.name: literals
Classes/DataType.html#/s:4Eval8DataTypeC.abstract: Array of literals that tell the framework how to transform certain types to an internal DataType representation

Classes/DataType.html#/s:4Eval8DataTypeC.name: init(type:literals:print:)
Classes/DataType.html#/s:4Eval8DataTypeC.abstract: To be able to bridge the outside world effectively, it needs to provide an already existing Swift or user-defined type. This can be class, struct, enum, or anything else, for example, block or function (which is not recommended).

Classes/DataType.html#/s:4Eval8DataTypeC.name: convert(input:interpreter:)
Classes/DataType.html#/s:4Eval8DataTypeC.abstract: For the conversion it uses the registered literals, to be able to process the input and return an existing type

Classes/DataType.html#/s:4Eval8DataTypeC.name: print(value:printer:)
Classes/DataType.html#/s:4Eval8DataTypeC.abstract: This is a convenience method, for debugging and value printing purposes, which can return a string from the current data type.

Classes/TypedInterpreter.html#/s:4Eval16.name: EvaluatedType
Classes/TypedInterpreter.html#/s:4Eval16.abstract: The result is a strongly typed value or nil (if it cannot be properly processed)

Classes/TypedInterpreter.html#/s:4Eval16.name: context
Classes/TypedInterpreter.html#/s:4Eval16.abstract: The global context used for every evaluation with this instance

Classes/TypedInterpreter.html#/s:4Eval16.name: interpreterForEvaluatingVariables
Classes/TypedInterpreter.html#/s:4Eval16.abstract: The interpreter used for evaluating variable values. In case of the TypedInterpreter, it’s itself

Classes/TypedInterpreter.html#/s:4Eval16.name: dataTypes
Classes/TypedInterpreter.html#/s:4Eval16.abstract: The data types that the expression is capable of recognise

Classes/TypedInterpreter.html#/s:4Eval16.name: functions
Classes/TypedInterpreter.html#/s:4Eval16.abstract: The list of functions that are available during the evaluation to process the recognised data types

Classes/TypedInterpreter.html#/s:4Eval16.name: functionCache
Classes/TypedInterpreter.html#/s:4Eval16.abstract: A cache of functions where expressions have matched before. This improves the performance a lot, when computing already established functions

Classes/TypedInterpreter.html#/s:4Eval16.name: dataTypeCache
Classes/TypedInterpreter.html#/s:4Eval16.abstract: A cache of data types where expressions have matched before. This improves the performance a lot, when computing already established data types

Classes/TypedInterpreter.html#/s:4Eval16.name: init(dataTypes:functions:context:)
Classes/TypedInterpreter.html#/s:4Eval16.abstract: Each item of the input list (data types, functions and the context) is optional, but strongly recommended to provide them. It’s usual that for every data type, there are a few functions provided, so the list can occasionally be pretty long.

Classes/TypedInterpreter.html#/s:4Eval16.name: evaluate(_:)
Classes/TypedInterpreter.html#/s:4Eval16.abstract: The evaluation method, that produces the strongly typed results. In this case, only the globally available context can be used

Classes/TypedInterpreter.html#/s:4Eval16.name: evaluate(_:context:)
Classes/TypedInterpreter.html#/s:4Eval16.abstract: The evaluation method, that produces the strongly typed results. In this case, only the context is a result of merging the global context and the one provided in the parameter

Classes/TypedInterpreter.html#/s:4Eval16.name: functionFromCache(for:using:connectedRanges:)
Classes/TypedInterpreter.html#/s:4Eval16.abstract: If the expression belongs to a cached function, it uses the function converter to evaluate it

Classes/TypedInterpreter.html#/s:4Eval16.name: dataTypeFromCache(for:)
Classes/TypedInterpreter.html#/s:4Eval16.abstract: If the expression belongs to a cached data type, it uses the data type converter to evaluate it

Classes/TypedInterpreter.html#/s:4Eval16.name: function(for:using:connectedRanges:)
Classes/TypedInterpreter.html#/s:4Eval16.abstract: If the expression is recognised as a function, it uses that function to evaluate the value

Classes/TypedInterpreter.html#/s:4Eval16.name: dataType(for:)
Classes/TypedInterpreter.html#/s:4Eval16.abstract: If the expression is recognised as a data type, it uses that data type to convert its value

Classes/TypedInterpreter.html#/s:4Eval16.name: variable(for:using:)
Classes/TypedInterpreter.html#/s:4Eval16.abstract: If the expression is recognised as a variable, it uses that variable to replace its value

Classes/TypedInterpreter.html#/s:4Eval16.name: print(_:)
Classes/TypedInterpreter.html#/s:4Eval16.abstract: A helper to be able to effectively print any result, coming out of the evaluation. The print method recognises the used data type and uses its string conversion block

Classes/TemplateVariable.html#/s:4Eval16.name: init(_:options:map:)
Classes/TemplateVariable.html#/s:4Eval16.abstract: No changes compared to the initialiser of the superclass Variable, uses the same parameters

Classes/StringTemplateInterpreter.html#/.name: EvaluatedType
Classes/StringTemplateInterpreter.html#/.abstract: The result of a template evaluation is a String

Classes/StringTemplateInterpreter.html#/.name: evaluate(_:context:)
Classes/StringTemplateInterpreter.html#/.abstract: The main part of the evaluation happens here. In this case, the global context variables merged with the provided context are going to be used.

Classes/TemplateInterpreter.html#/s:4Eva.name: statements
Classes/TemplateInterpreter.html#/s:4Eva.abstract: The statements (patterns) registered to the interpreter. If found, these are going to be processed and replaced with the evaluated value

Classes/TemplateInterpreter.html#/s:4Eva.name: context
Classes/TemplateInterpreter.html#/s:4Eva.abstract: The context used when evaluating the expressions. These context variables are global, used in every evaluation processed with this instance.

Classes/TemplateInterpreter.html#/s:4Eva.name: typedInterpreter
Classes/TemplateInterpreter.html#/s:4Eva.abstract: The StringTemplateInterpreter contains a TypedInterpreter, as it is quite common practice to evaluate strongly typed expression as s support for the template language.

Classes/TemplateInterpreter.html#/s:4Eva.name: VariableEvaluator
Classes/TemplateInterpreter.html#/s:4Eva.abstract: The evaluator type that is being used to process variables. By default, the TypedInterpreter is being used

Classes/TemplateInterpreter.html#/s:4Eva.name: EvaluatedType
Classes/TemplateInterpreter.html#/s:4Eva.abstract: The result type of a template evaluation

Classes/TemplateInterpreter.html#/s:4Eva.name: interpreterForEvaluatingVariables
Classes/TemplateInterpreter.html#/s:4Eva.abstract: The evaluator, that is being used to process variables

Classes/TemplateInterpreter.html#/s:4Eva.name: init(statements:interpreter:context:)
Classes/TemplateInterpreter.html#/s:4Eva.abstract: The statements, and context parameters are optional, but highly recommended to use with actual values.

Classes/TemplateInterpreter.html#/s:4Eva.name: evaluate(_:)
Classes/TemplateInterpreter.html#/s:4Eva.abstract: The main part of the evaluation happens here. In this case, only the global context variables are going to be used

Classes/TemplateInterpreter.html#/s:4Eva.name: evaluate(_:context:)
Classes/TemplateInterpreter.html#/s:4Eva.abstract: The main part of the evaluation happens here. In this case, the global context variables merged with the provided context are going to be used.

Classes/TemplateInterpreter.html#/s:4Eva.name: Reducer
Classes/TemplateInterpreter.html#/s:4Eva.abstract: Reduce block can convet a stream of values into one, by calling this block for every element, returning a single value at the end. The concept is usually used in functional environments

Classes/TemplateInterpreter.html#/s:4Eva.name: TemplateReducer
Classes/TemplateInterpreter.html#/s:4Eva.abstract: In order to support generic types, not just plain String objects, a reducer helps to convert the output to the dedicated output type

Classes/TemplateInterpreter.html#/s:4Eva.name: evaluate(_:context:reducer:)
Classes/TemplateInterpreter.html#/s:4Eva.abstract: The main part of the evaluation happens here. In this case, the global context variables merged with the provided context are going to be used.

Classes/GenericVariable.html#/s:4Eval15G.name: VariableMapper
Classes/GenericVariable.html#/s:4Eval15G.abstract: Maps and validates the variable value to another

Classes/GenericVariable.html#/s:4Eval15G.name: name
Classes/GenericVariable.html#/s:4Eval15G.abstract: Unique identifier of the variable that is used when matching and returning them in the matcher.

Classes/GenericVariable.html#/s:4Eval15G.name: options
Classes/GenericVariable.html#/s:4Eval15G.abstract: Options that modify the behaviour of the variable matching, and the output that the framework provides

Classes/GenericVariable.html#/s:4Eval15G.name: map
Classes/GenericVariable.html#/s:4Eval15G.abstract: The result of the evaluated variable will be running through this map function, transforming its value. By default the map tries to convert the matched value to the expected type, using the as? operator.

Classes/GenericVariable.html#/s:4Eval15G.name: matches(prefix:options:)
Classes/GenericVariable.html#/s:4Eval15G.abstract: GenericVariables always return anyMatch MatchResult, forwarding the shortest argument, provided during initialisation

Classes/GenericVariable.html#/s:4Eval15G.name: mapped(_:)
Classes/GenericVariable.html#/s:4Eval15G.abstract: A helper method to map the value of the current variable to another type

Classes/GenericVariable.html#/s:4Eval15G.name: performMap(input:interpreter:)
Classes/GenericVariable.html#/s:4Eval15G.abstract: The result of the evaluated variable will be ran through this map function, transforming its value. By default the map tries to convert the matched value to the expected type, using the as? operator.

Classes/CloseKeyword.html#/s:4Eval12Clos.name: init(_:)
Classes/CloseKeyword.html#/s:4Eval12Clos.abstract: The initialiser uses the closing type, but the name still must be provided

Classes/OpenKeyword.html#/s:4Eval11OpenK.name: init(_:)
Classes/OpenKeyword.html#/s:4Eval11OpenK.abstract: The initialiser uses the opening type, but the name still must be provided

Classes/Keyword/KeywordType.html#/s:4Eva.name: generic
Classes/Keyword/KeywordType.html#/s:4Eva.abstract: By default, Keyword is created as a generic type, meaning, that there is no special requirement, that they need to fulfil

Classes/Keyword/KeywordType.html#/s:4Eva.name: openingStatement
Classes/Keyword/KeywordType.html#/s:4Eva.abstract: If a pattern contains two, semantically paired Keywords, they often represent opening and closing parentheses or any special enclosing characters.

Classes/Keyword/KeywordType.html#/s:4Eva.name: closingStatement
Classes/Keyword/KeywordType.html#/s:4Eva.abstract: If a pattern contains two, semantically paired Keywords, they often represent opening and closing parentheses or any special enclosing characters.

Classes/Keyword/KeywordType.html.name: KeywordType
Classes/Keyword/KeywordType.html.abstract: The type of the Keyword determines whether the item holds some special purpose, or it’s just an ordinary static String

Classes/Keyword.html#/s:4Eval7KeywordC4t.name: type
Classes/Keyword.html#/s:4Eval7KeywordC4t.abstract: Type of the keyword, which gives the framework some extra semantics about its nature

Classes/Keyword.html#/s:4Eval7KeywordC7m.name: matches(prefix:options:)
Classes/Keyword.html#/s:4Eval7KeywordC7m.abstract: Keyword instances are returning exactMatch, when they are equal to the prefix input.

Classes/Context.html#/s:4Eval7ContextC5s.name: stack
Classes/Context.html#/s:4Eval7ContextC5s.abstract: Context can behave as a stack. If push is called, it saves a snapshot of the current state of variables to a stack and lets you modify the content, while the previous values are stored, safely.

Classes/Context.html#/s:4Eval7ContextC9v.name: init(variables:)
Classes/Context.html#/s:4Eval7ContextC9v.abstract: Users of the context may optionally provide an initial set of variables

Classes/Context.html#/s:4Eval7ContextC4p.name: push()
Classes/Context.html#/s:4Eval7ContextC4p.abstract: Context can behave as a stack. If push is called, it saves a snapshot of the current state of variables to a stack and lets you modify the content, while the previous values are stored, safely.

Classes/Context.html#/s:4Eval7ContextC3p.name: pop()
Classes/Context.html#/s:4Eval7ContextC3p.abstract: Context can behave as a stack. If push is called, it saves a snapshot of the current state of variables to a stack and lets you modify the content, while the previous values are stored, safely.

Classes/Context.html#/s:4Eval7ContextC7m.name: merging(with:)
Classes/Context.html#/s:4Eval7ContextC7m.abstract: Creates a new context instance by merging their variable dictionaries. The one in the parameter overrides the duplicated items of the existing one

Classes/Context.html#/s:4Eval7ContextC5m.name: merge(with:merge:)
Classes/Context.html#/s:4Eval7ContextC5m.abstract: Modifies the current context instance by merging its variable dictionary with the parameter. The one in the parameter overrides the duplicated items of the existing one

Classes/Context.html.name: Context
Classes/Context.html.abstract: The only responsibility of the InterpreterContext class is to store variables, and keep them during the execution, where multiple expressions might use the same set of variables.

Classes/Keyword.html.name: Keyword
Classes/Keyword.html.abstract: Keyword instances are used to provide static points in match sequences so that they can be used as pillars of the expressions the developer tries to match

Classes/OpenKeyword.html.name: OpenKeyword
Classes/OpenKeyword.html.abstract: A special subclass of the Keyword class, which initialises a Keyword with an opening type.

Classes/CloseKeyword.html.name: CloseKeyword
Classes/CloseKeyword.html.abstract: A special subclass of the Keyword class, which initialises a Keyword with an closing type.

Classes/GenericVariable.html.name: GenericVariable
Classes/GenericVariable.html.abstract: Generic superclass of Variables which are aware of their Interpreter classes,

Classes/TemplateInterpreter.html.name: TemplateInterpreter
Classes/TemplateInterpreter.html.abstract: This interpreter is used to evaluate string expressions and return a transformed string, replacing the content where it matches certain patterns.

Classes/StringTemplateInterpreter.html.name: StringTemplateInterpreter
Classes/StringTemplateInterpreter.html.abstract: This interpreter is used to evaluate string expressions and return a transformed string, replacing the content where it matches certain patterns.

Classes/TemplateVariable.html.name: TemplateVariable
Classes/TemplateVariable.html.abstract: A special kind of variable that is used in case of StringTemplateInterpreters. It does not convert its content using the interpreterForEvaluatingVariables but always uses the StringTemplateInterpreter instance.

Classes/TypedInterpreter.html.name: TypedInterpreter
Classes/TypedInterpreter.html.abstract: A type of interpreter implementation that is capable of evaluating arbitrary string expressions to strongly typed variables

Classes/DataType.html.name: DataType
Classes/DataType.html.abstract: The implementation of a DataType uses the DataTypeProtocol to convert input to a strongly typed data and print it if needed

Classes/Literal.html.name: Literal
Classes/Literal.html.abstract: Literals are used by DataTypes to be able to recognise static values, that can be expressed as a given type

Classes/Function.html.name: Function
Classes/Function.html.abstract: Functions can process values in given DataTypes, allowing the expressions to be feature-rich

Classes.html#/s:4Eval8VariableC.name: Variable
Classes.html#/s:4Eval8VariableC.abstract: Variable represents a named placeholder, so when the matcher recognises a pattern, the values of the variables are passed to them in a block.

Classes/VariableProcessor.html.name: VariableProcessor
Classes/VariableProcessor.html.abstract: A processor that can process a raw value with extra information, such as interpreter and context

Classes/Matcher.html.name: Matcher
Classes/Matcher.html.abstract: This class provides the main logic of the Eval framework, performing the pattern matching details

Typealiases.html.name: Type Aliases
Typealiases.html.abstract: The following type aliases are available globally.
